comments.commentBody: I think that we should have a moonshot to find ways to stop earthquakes, volcanos, and hurricanes in the next 10 years. Overcoming forces of nature is far more difficult than carrying out a targeted, if complex, engineering feet. Cancer is a bit more like a force of nature than an engineering problem, although there are ways to make steady slow progress on some parts of it.
So right.  And as an idiotic name, the "War on Gun Violence" is the best.
Delicious! No big hassle to make at home and a tasty dinner with a tiny bit of prep.

JC is completely mistaken.  "Business" in any form is utterly wrong as a measure of research laboratories.  "Efficiency" is also wrong.  Misuse of funds is wrong, but normal business standards are antithetical to successful research.
You mean, stop aging?  That is ambitious.

ObamaCare increased the amount of money Americans are paying for health care and that excess money is all going into the pockets of Big Medicine. As intended. The drug companies, the big hospital chains [like the non-profit hospital that paid $350,000 to Michelle Obama for a part time job] and the insurance companies are not going to give up any of their profits. The insurers are already complaining that Obama didn't live up to his promise to guarantee them a profit on their exchange policies.

Moving from fossil fuels to renewable energy increases the amount of money Americans pay for electricity and adds money to the pockets of Buffet, Imelt, Steyer and Musk. The fossil fuel industries get $8 billion in tax breaks on their tax bills. The renewable industries pay no taxes and get gifts from the taxpayer of $14 billion and raise the cost of electricity to consumers while they are at it. The cronies are on the renewable energy side. Personally, I think that all energy subsidies should end.

What Bernie knows, but doesn't want his followers to find out, it that you cannot raise taxes on the rich, because they have lots of ways of avoiding taxes. He is honest in saying the middle class has to pay for his programs.

Arun.....yes, what must be explained is why the medical industry corporations in other countries allow govts to negotiate and regulate medical costs, so the OECD average is 9.3.

What are their profits like compared to unregulated US corporations? Why don't they lobby and push billions into political campaigns to ensure laws to keep health care as a big profit center? Why doesn't Krugman ever talk about this?

Why do other countries move from fossil fuels to renewable energy at a greater rate than the US? Why do their Supreme Courts not block this, as ours is doing? Surely these countries' big business loves profits too. Yet their societies, with all their differences, are able to cooperate in basic components of democracy.

They use much more public funding of elections, and actually limit private donations. This is not seen as dictatorial big govt interfering with 'free speech'. But let's keep that dark, in case it might give Americans some threatening ideas.
And Arun, that 7.6% of GDP will go along way towards funding Bernie's programs to help the people who are not wealthy.

In 2012, the US spent 16.9% of GDP on health care. The OECD average was 9.3%. Any attempt to make the US average more like the OECD average is going to take upto 7.6% of the GDP out of the pockets of a bunch of people who are wealthy enough to fund a lot of hatred.

Similarly, moving from fossil fuels to renewable energy threatens enough monied interests to buy a whole lot more of hatred.

And like it or not, Bernie Sanders is correct in that politicians can't claim to be immune from the influence of money.

What is not clear is why their propaganda works with the electorate.

This was very disappointing. I did not have peanut oil but used coconut oil. That was the only change. It was very bland. I ate one and then added salt and pepper. Still was not what I was hoping. My thought is that some garlic powder and perhaps basil would have helped.
Debbie R and Mike are both on the beam.
Ross is not the issue.. there is anger at Washington for our non-functional Democracy.. and Ross didn't cause that phenomenon.
Although denying the Executive his/her right to appoint someone to the Judicial branch would certainly exacerbate the issue.  Who needs a functioning court system anyways.. world powers? *scoffs*

Oh yeah? What frenzy is that? "How America was lost" by the Republicans temporarily blocking a Supreme Court nomination? Really?

I don't think it is an overreaction to recognize that there is an almost complete absence of reasoned discussion in the media or that what little there is gets drowned out by frenetic audience building. I don't think its an overreaction to suggest that the media's imperative to serve advertisers is reducing our experiment in self-government to competing mobs yelling at one another for the entertainment of an audience.

Mr. Krugman is insufficiently informed about American political history.

Senator McConnell advises that the Senate should not confirm another U.S. Supreme Court nominee under President Obama.

“We should reverse the presumption of confirmation,” McConnell told the American Constitution Society convention in Washington. “The Supreme Court is dangerously out of balance. We cannot afford to see Justice Scalia replaced by another Sotomajor, or Justice Renquist by another Kagan.”

Now, substitute Schumer for McConnell, Bush for Obama, Scalia by Stevens, Sotomajor by Roberts and Alito by Ginsburg and you have , precisely, the advice of Senator Charles E. Schumer, (D, NY) in 2007 to his fellow Democrats.

http://www.politico.com/story/2007/07/schumer-to-fight-new-bush-high-cou...

Yes; women are heroines, at every stage of their lives, designated as such by their gender definition. Just don't worry about what is upcoming, and deal with what you are in, solving each stage at a time!
Best of luck for all women

I also believe that menopause is something that should be celebrated. While I am only eighteen years old and haven't experienced it yet, I have watched as my best friend's mother has gone through it. Her's was beginning to be so bad that she had to have surgery to help ease the pains. My mother had it early on after she had a hysterectomy. It is a very painful stage of life for many women, and deserves to be given more attention. Women go through so much pain as they go through life, from cramps during menstrual cycles, to giving birth, then to menopause. I don't think women get enough credit for it all. My older sister is having her second child and she is experiencing symptoms far worse than with her first pregnancy. I'm not looking forward to menopause because my periods are already terribly painful, irregular, and last longer than they should. I'm longing for the day when I know longer have to worry about when it will be my time of the month. Men should be more empathetic for all the pain women go through for them. But menopause will always be there as a sign of aging, so why not embrace it and celebrate?

NRroad seems to know about vapid posturing.  I prefer facts.  How many treaties have you negotiated lately?  Or your Republican admirees?  Sorry, I almost forgot their off-the-books treaty with Netanyahu.
Nope.  They will cook just fine.  Been doing this for 40 years.
Adding to Miff's valuable comment, for a sexually transmitted cancer agent we also have to overcome the "no-talk-about-sex" and "she-deserves-it" attitudes on the part of much of the population.

Thanks!
The speech is available here:
https://www.acslaw.org/news/video/senator-schumer-discusses-the-supreme-...

I'm sure that surveillance video has already been studied and that a tall suspicious looking man with a dark complexion, close-cropped and graying hair, and wearing a white 10-gallon hat pulled down around the front of his head was seen knocking on the door of the deceased Justice's resort accommodations during the time period he was thought to have died. The Duck is no doubt on the case and will make an announcement for maximum effect.

You are laboring under the misconception that Trump is a Republican. He is a crony socialist and has given far more contributions to Democrats over his lifetime.

Republicans do not have any objection to Obama nominating new justices. He should not have any objection to their not being confirmed unless they are qualified.
Clearly it was Hilary Clinton who offed Scalia in preparation of her upcoming November victory...

The only thing that surprises me is that no member of the GOP has, to my knowledge, blamed Justice Scalia's death on President Obama.  I certainly wouldn't put it past The Donald to come up with such an accusation (even if he's still working on the location of that missing Kenyan birth certificate).  Nor would I be surprised if such an allegation were delivered by Marco Rubio who just this weekend found a way to blame former President Clinton for the attacks on 9/11.  And, of course, Ted Cruz took it upon himself to lead the charge against the Senate even considering any of the President's potential nominees to fill Mr. Scalia's position.  So little time had elapsed between the announcement of the Justice's death and the launching of this latest Cruz missile that one might have been forgiven for assuming that the Senator had simply jumped the gun again as per his staffers' contention that Ben Carson had put his presidential campaign on "hold" (did Cruz even wait for the last rites to be performed?). Naturally, these are the same people who so admired Justice Scalia for his (supposedly) adhering to every syllable and particle of punctuation to be found in the Constitution.  On the other hand, President Obama's insistence on exercising his constitutional authority to nominate new justices to the highest office in the land doesn't impress them quite so much.
Ended up taking a lot longer to bake than the cited 22 min. Ultimately we'd say it's more scone-like than biscuit and definitely add more baking time to get golden tops.

.
JFC,
Will trust you re your facts. Wish to add that Bork was less a nominee than a provocation, politically. Oconnor & Scalia got fast approval with few if any NOES.

News reports tell me that many cases that were likely 5-4 will now be 4-4, meaning Scalia held decisive vote. He was nominated by a prez elected 35 years ago. So built-in checks and balances are best served if a prez who has won 61+% of Electoral College twice this Century sends a nominee to a Senate that is 54% Republican.

The new Justice would, one suspects, resolve those tie votes if the cases are reargued. Seems perfect.

You mentioned Charles's church connection to the late Justice. Learned today that J. Scalia worked in Cleveland for Jones Day. Weren't you with a Cleveland outfit? Also, Son Scalia got law degree @ U. Chicago, now with Gibson Dunn.

My favorite is that the Justice's dad (immigrant) was professor @ Brooklyn College, where my mom got her degree. But Bernie Sanders went there too, then transferred - to U. Chicago!

You know I met the Justice, yes? His intellect was palpable. Also an intensely focussed listener, during Q & A and in our private chat. I told him it was an honor to have him eviscerate my question in the Q & A. It really was intellectually challenging, like Krozel clues.

Oh, and Ms. Totenberg should perhaps recuse from covering Senate proceedings. I like her coverage of cases under consideration, tho. Jan Crawford & Joan Biskupic are better explainers of rulings. Chicagoans?

I always add sesame oil to the pork mixture, proportional to the amount of meat, maybe upwards of 2 tsp to a pound of meat (depends on how much you like sesame oil), plus some soy sauce.  Note - dabbing some water around the edge of the wrapper with a brush works just as well as egg to seal them and is a bit less messy.

I agree with not following Charles Schumer's advice. On the other hand, George W. Bush is the same president who nominated the grossly unqualified Harriet Miers to the Supreme Court, and allegedly want to nominate Alberto Gonzales to the Supreme Court as well.
Well, here's one Democrat who WILL make a big deal of it, and I think I am not alone.  We'll do our best from the bleachers, and the DNC and the candidates have to do theirs on the field.
You are far too cynical about Democrats. This is a layup for them.

Unless Democrats make a huge deal out of the GOP-led Senate's intransigence over not approving whomever President Obama nominates, there won't be any fallout for Republicans, none at all. In fact, in the face of Democratic silence or whining the GOP might energize its base.

Were the President to nominate someone who could spur Democratic support and a public outcry, then the GOP Senate might think twice about holding up the President's Constitutional duties. Will the President think this strategically. Probably not. Would he get the Democrats on board? Again, probably not.

But I doubt it'll get that far. That Democratic Party disappeared a generation ago. The current one mostly seems to do whatever Wall Street and Silicon Valley tell it to. I'm willing to be surprised, though.
Espresso. Darn that spell check.

What many have learned since 2008 is essentially this:

-How big corporate money finances America s election campaigns.

-That the two corporate parties ignore their constituencies and carryout policies benefiting the rich and powerful, the 1 percent rather than the citizens.

-A thing called the feedback loop, how corporate wealth translates into political power through campaign financing, corporate lobbying, and that revolving door of jobs between government and private industry.

-And globalization which is a race to the bottom and how it tilted the balance of power toward corporations and away from workers.

In summary, the system is rigged. Charts, graphs, diagrams will not change the corruption. Sometimes I feel like I am living in the Twilight Zone.
Citizens United. Now there's bad taste.

You are clearly not a writer. Followes is just tying up the loose ends into soon-to-be clearer
plot resolutions.
I suggest you try writing a massive work of epic proportions for six-seven years, to international popularity and acclaim before mouthing off your vinegary opinions.
A truly cheap shot reply; one wonders, indeed, why some of you DO watch!
It's far from clear that Fellowes is a writer!

Golly, Out-of-Stater, you sure read Sharon J's comments as being a lot meaner than I think they are or were meant to be! Take a deep breath and think calm thoughts...we're just sharing our opinions about something we all enjoy watching, one way or another.

What a strange episode. It felt like a jumbled bunch of moments strung together without much cohesion. I would have liked a little less cars-around-the-track action and more of the dowager, though it seemed out of character for her to make secret departure to France, leaving behind a note with Isobel and a puppy with the staff. (Cute puppy, though.) As far as the noble daughters go, Edith curled up against Bertie was charming and natural, while the scenes between Mary and Henry were oddly boring. On to next week, I guess.

@Steve, that may be true, but the Crawleys speak about him as if he were essentially "penniless" and had no financial prospects to speak of, and Henry tends to speak of himself in much the same manner.

Bit early in the timeline for the Bentley Boys.
I hope we get to the General Strike. I'll bet Daisy is a real firebrand.

"Henry T, a penniless, danger-courting professional driver."
Who buys his own Bentley? No cheaper then than they are now. He may not have as much money as the Crawleys, but he's probably better off than most of us.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bentley_Boys
